docs.text: Recap ¶ Recap makes it easy for engineers to build infrastructure and tools that need metadata. Unlike traditional data catalogs, Recap is designed to power software. Read Recap: A Data Catalog for People Who Hate Data Catalogs to learn more. Features ¶ Supports major cloud data warehouses and PostgreSQL No external system dependencies required Designed for the CLI Runs as a Python library or REST API Fully pluggable Installation ¶ pip install recap-core Commands ¶ recap catalog list - List a data catalog directory. recap catalog read - Read metadata from the data catalog. recap catalog search - Search the data catalog for metadata. recap crawl - Crawl infrastructure and save metadata in the data catalog. recap plugins analyzers - List all analyzer plugins. recap plugins browsers - List all browser plugins. recap plugins catalogs - List all catalog plugins. recap plugins commands - List all command plugins. recap serve - Start Recap's REST API. Getting Started ¶ See the Quickstart page to get started.
docs.title: Home

docs.text: Recap analyzers generate metadata; they're given a path and return a Pydantic model with the metadata the analyzer discovered. Database Analyzers ¶ Recap ships with the following analyzer plugins: db.location sqlalchemy.access sqlalchemy.columns sqlalchemy.comment sqlalchemy.foreign_keys sqlalchemy.indexes sqlalchemy.primary_key sqlalchemy.profile sqlalchemy.view_definition Other analyzers will be available if you've installed additional analyzer plugins . Run recap plugins analyzers to see a complete list. Note Analyzers namespace prefixes differentiate analyzers that return similar data. The SQLAlchemy sqlalchemy.columns analyzer returns column schemas in the standard SQLAlchemy schema format. A more specific snowflake.columns analyzer could return a more Snowflake-specific schema. Clients decide which analyzer metadata to use. Access ¶ Returns user access information for a table or view. "sqlalchemy.access" : { "<username>" : { "privileges" : [ "INSERT" , "SELECT" , "UPDATE" , "DELETE" , "TRUNCATE" , "REFERENCES" , "TRIGGER" ], "read" : true , "write" : true } } Column ¶ Returns column schemas. "sqlalchemy.columns" : { "email" : { "autoincrement" : false , "default" : null , "generic_type" : "VARCHAR" , "nullable" : false , "type" : "VARCHAR" }, "id" : { "autoincrement" : true , "default" : "nextval('\"some_db\".some_table_id_seq'::regclass)" , "generic_type" : "BIGINT" , "nullable" : false , "type" : "BIGINT" } } Comment ¶ Returns a table's coment, if any. "sqlalchemy.comment" : "The roles that can be applied to the current user." Foreign Key ¶ Returns foreign key information. "sqlalchemy.foreign_keys" : [ { "constrained_columns" : [ "some_id" ], "name" : "fk_some_id" , "options" : {}, "referred_columns" : [ "id" ], "referred_schema" : "some_schema" , "referred_table" : "some_table" } ] Index ¶ Returns index information. "sqlalchemy.indexes" : { "index_some_table_on_email" : { "columns" : [ "email" ], "unique" : false } } Location ¶ Returns the type, instance, schema, and table/view location. "db.location" : { "database" : "postgresql" , "instance" : "localhost" , "schema" : "some_db" , "table" : "some_table" } Primary Key ¶ Returns primary key information "sqlalchemy.primary_key" : { "constrained_columns" : [ "id" ], "name" : "some_table_pkey" } Profile ¶ Returns basic table statistics (max, min, nulls, count, and so on). "sqlalchemy.profile" : { "email" : { "count" : 10 , "distinct" : 10 , "empty_strings" : 0 , "max_length" : 32 , "min_length" : 13 , "nulls" : 0 }, "id" : { "average" : 5.5 , "count" : 10 , "max" : 10 , "min" : 1 , "negatives" : 0 , "nulls" : 0 , "sum" : 55.0 , "zeros" : 0 } } View Definitions ¶ Returns a view's query, if any. "sqlalchemy.view_definition" : "SELECT * FROM table;"
docs.title: Analyzers

docs.text: Recap ships with the following analyzer plugins: db.location sqlalchemy.access sqlalchemy.columns sqlalchemy.comment sqlalchemy.foreign_keys sqlalchemy.indexes sqlalchemy.primary_key sqlalchemy.profile sqlalchemy.view_definition Other analyzers will be available if you've installed additional analyzer plugins . Run recap plugins analyzers to see a complete list. Note Analyzers namespace prefixes differentiate analyzers that return similar data. The SQLAlchemy sqlalchemy.columns analyzer returns column schemas in the standard SQLAlchemy schema format. A more specific snowflake.columns analyzer could return a more Snowflake-specific schema. Clients decide which analyzer metadata to use.

docs.text: Different data infrastructure have different types of objects (tables, columns, files, topics, partitions, and so on). Recap uses a browser abstraction map infrastructure objects into a standard directory format. A different browser is used for each type of infrastructure. Browsers do not actually analyze a system's data for metadata; they simply show what's available. Recap comes with a database browser and a filesystem browser. Other browsers can be implemented and added as plugins . Root Paths ¶ Browsers expose a root path, which defines where a data system will be located in Recap's data catalog. The DatabaseBrowser 's root path format is: /databases/{scheme}/instances/{name} So, a DatabaseBrowser for a PostgreSQL might have a root path like: /databases/postgresql/instances/prd-profile-db Database Browser ¶ DatabaseBrowser browses different databases and maps their database objects into a directory structure: /schemas /schemas/{schema} /schemas/{schema}/tables /schemas/{schema}/tables/{table} /schemas/{schema}/views /schemas/{schema}/views/{view} This full directory path (including the root) is what you use when you run recap catalog list and recap catalog read . The directory structure is also used when executing recap crawl with a --filter option. Note Recap uses SQLAlchemy as its database abstraction, so any SQLAlchemy dialect should work if you've installed the appropriate package. Filesystem Browser ¶ FilesystemBrowser browses both local filesystems and remote object stores like S3, GCS, and ABS. The directory structure format mirrors the crawled filesystem. Note Recap uses fsspec as its filesystem abstraction, so any known built-in or other known implementation should work.
docs.title: Browsers

docs.text: Browsers expose a root path, which defines where a data system will be located in Recap's data catalog. The DatabaseBrowser 's root path format is: /databases/{scheme}/instances/{name} So, a DatabaseBrowser for a PostgreSQL might have a root path like: /databases/postgresql/instances/prd-profile-db
docs.title: Root Paths

docs.text: DatabaseBrowser browses different databases and maps their database objects into a directory structure: /schemas /schemas/{schema} /schemas/{schema}/tables /schemas/{schema}/tables/{table} /schemas/{schema}/views /schemas/{schema}/views/{view} This full directory path (including the root) is what you use when you run recap catalog list and recap catalog read . The directory structure is also used when executing recap crawl with a --filter option. Note Recap uses SQLAlchemy as its database abstraction, so any SQLAlchemy dialect should work if you've installed the appropriate package.
docs.title: Database Browser

docs.text: FilesystemBrowser browses both local filesystems and remote object stores like S3, GCS, and ABS. The directory structure format mirrors the crawled filesystem. Note Recap uses fsspec as its filesystem abstraction, so any known built-in or other known implementation should work.
docs.title: Filesystem Browser

docs.text: Recap catalogs store metadata and expose read and search APIs. Recap ships with a database catalog and Recap catalog implementation. The database catalog is enabled by default (with SQLite). Database Catalog ¶ The database catalog uses SQLAlchemy to persists catalog data. By default, a SQLite database is used; the file is located in ~/.recap/catalog/recap.db . Search is implemented using SQLite's json_extract syntax syntax. See Commands for an example. You can configure the SQLite catalog in your settings.toml like so: [catalog] url = "sqlite://" engine . connect_args . check_same_thread = false Anything under the engine namespace will be forwarded to the SQLAlchemy engine. You can use any SQLAlchemy dialect with the database catalog. Here's a settings.toml that's configured for PostgreSQL: [catalog] url = "postgresql://user:pass@localhost/some_db" Recap Catalog ¶ The Recap catalog makes HTTP requests to a Recap server . [catalog] plugin = "recap" url = "http://localhost:8000" The Recap catalog enables different systems to share the same metadata when they all talk to the same Recap server.
docs.title: Catalogs

docs.text: The database catalog uses SQLAlchemy to persists catalog data. By default, a SQLite database is used; the file is located in ~/.recap/catalog/recap.db . Search is implemented using SQLite's json_extract syntax syntax. See Commands for an example. You can configure the SQLite catalog in your settings.toml like so: [catalog] url = "sqlite://" engine . connect_args . check_same_thread = false Anything under the engine namespace will be forwarded to the SQLAlchemy engine. You can use any SQLAlchemy dialect with the database catalog. Here's a settings.toml that's configured for PostgreSQL: [catalog] url = "postgresql://user:pass@localhost/some_db"
docs.title: Database Catalog

docs.text: The Recap catalog makes HTTP requests to a Recap server . [catalog] plugin = "recap" url = "http://localhost:8000" The Recap catalog enables different systems to share the same metadata when they all talk to the same Recap server.
docs.title: Recap Catalog

docs.text: Recap ships with several standard command plugins: recap crawl recap plugins recap serve Note You can see all available commands by running recap --help or recap plugins commands . Catalog ¶ Recap's recap catalog command reads metadata Recap's data catalog. List the catalog's directory structure with recap list , read metadata from a directory with recap read , and search with recap search . Search ¶ Recap's search syntax depends on the Catalog plugin that's used. As mentioned in the Quickstart , Recap stores its metadata in SQLite by default. You can use SQLite's json_extract syntax to search the catalog: recap catalog search "json_extract(metadata, '$.\"db.location\".table') = 'some_table'" The database file defaults to ~/.recap/catalog/recap.db , if you wish to open a SQLite client directly. Crawl ¶ Use recap crawl to crawl infrastructure and store its metadata in Recap's catalog. The crawl command takes an optional URL parameter. If specified, the URL will be crawled. If not specified, all crawlers defined in your settings.toml file will be crawled (see Configuration for more information). Excludes ¶ You might not want to use all analyzers when crawling infrastrucutre. Some analyzers (particularly the profile analyzer) are costly and slow to run. To exclude an analyzer, use --exclude with recap crawl . For example: recap crawl postgresql://username@localhost/some_db --exclude='sqlalchemy.profile' Filters ¶ Recap crawls all paths by default, which can be slow. You might wish to only crawl some subset of data. You can use --filter to control what data the crawler looks at. Recap uses Unix filename pattern matching as defined in Python's fnmatch module. To crawl only a specific table, you would use this syntax: recap crawl postgresql://username@localhost/some_db --filter='/**/tables/some_table' Plugins ¶ The recap plugins command lists the Recap plugins that you have installed in your environment. To list the available analyzers, run this command: recap plugins analyzers [ "db.location", "sqlalchemy.access", "sqlalchemy.columns", "sqlalchemy.comment", "sqlalchemy.foreign_keys", "sqlalchemy.indexes", "sqlalchemy.primary_key", "sqlalchemy.profile", "sqlalchemy.view_definition" ] See recap plugins --help for more. Serve ¶ You might wish to centralize your Recap data catalog in one place, and have all users read from the same location. Recap ships with an HTTP/JSON server for this use case. Start a Recap server on a single host using recap serve . Clients can then configure their Recap catalog in settings.toml to point to the server location: [catalog] type = "recap" url = "http://192.168.0.1:8000" See the server documentation for more information.
docs.title: Commands

docs.text: Recap's recap catalog command reads metadata Recap's data catalog. List the catalog's directory structure with recap list , read metadata from a directory with recap read , and search with recap search .
docs.title: Catalog

docs.text: Recap's search syntax depends on the Catalog plugin that's used. As mentioned in the Quickstart , Recap stores its metadata in SQLite by default. You can use SQLite's json_extract syntax to search the catalog: recap catalog search "json_extract(metadata, '$.\"db.location\".table') = 'some_table'" The database file defaults to ~/.recap/catalog/recap.db , if you wish to open a SQLite client directly.
docs.title: Search

docs.text: Use recap crawl to crawl infrastructure and store its metadata in Recap's catalog. The crawl command takes an optional URL parameter. If specified, the URL will be crawled. If not specified, all crawlers defined in your settings.toml file will be crawled (see Configuration for more information).
docs.title: Crawl

docs.text: You might not want to use all analyzers when crawling infrastrucutre. Some analyzers (particularly the profile analyzer) are costly and slow to run. To exclude an analyzer, use --exclude with recap crawl . For example: recap crawl postgresql://username@localhost/some_db --exclude='sqlalchemy.profile'
docs.title: Excludes

docs.text: Recap crawls all paths by default, which can be slow. You might wish to only crawl some subset of data. You can use --filter to control what data the crawler looks at. Recap uses Unix filename pattern matching as defined in Python's fnmatch module. To crawl only a specific table, you would use this syntax: recap crawl postgresql://username@localhost/some_db --filter='/**/tables/some_table'
docs.title: Filters

docs.text: The recap plugins command lists the Recap plugins that you have installed in your environment. To list the available analyzers, run this command: recap plugins analyzers [ "db.location", "sqlalchemy.access", "sqlalchemy.columns", "sqlalchemy.comment", "sqlalchemy.foreign_keys", "sqlalchemy.indexes", "sqlalchemy.primary_key", "sqlalchemy.profile", "sqlalchemy.view_definition" ] See recap plugins --help for more.
docs.title: Plugins

docs.text: You might wish to centralize your Recap data catalog in one place, and have all users read from the same location. Recap ships with an HTTP/JSON server for this use case. Start a Recap server on a single host using recap serve . Clients can then configure their Recap catalog in settings.toml to point to the server location: [catalog] type = "recap" url = "http://192.168.0.1:8000" See the server documentation for more information.
docs.title: Serve

docs.text: Though Recap's CLI can run without any configuration, you might want to configure Recap using a config file. Recap uses Dynaconf for its configuration system. Config Locations ¶ Configuraton is stored in ~/.recap/settings.toml by default. You can override the default location by setting the SETTINGS_FILE_FOR_DYNACONF environment variable. See Dynaconf's documentation for more information. Schema ¶ Recap's settings.toml has two main sections: catalog and crawlers . The catalog section configures the storage layer; it uses SQLite by default. Run recap plugins catalogs to see other options. The crawlers section defines infrastructure to crawl. Only the url field is required. You may optionally specify analyzer excludes and path filters as well. [catalog] plugin = "recap" url = "http://localhost:8000" [[crawlers]] url = "postgresql://username@localhost/some_db" excludes = [ "sqlalchemy.profile" ] filters = [ "/**/tables/some_table" ] Secrets ¶ Do not store database credentials in your settings.toml ; use Dynaconf's secret management instead. See Dynaconf's documentation for more information.
docs.title: Configuration

docs.text: Configuraton is stored in ~/.recap/settings.toml by default. You can override the default location by setting the SETTINGS_FILE_FOR_DYNACONF environment variable. See Dynaconf's documentation for more information.
docs.title: Config Locations

docs.text: Recap's settings.toml has two main sections: catalog and crawlers . The catalog section configures the storage layer; it uses SQLite by default. Run recap plugins catalogs to see other options. The crawlers section defines infrastructure to crawl. Only the url field is required. You may optionally specify analyzer excludes and path filters as well. [catalog] plugin = "recap" url = "http://localhost:8000" [[crawlers]] url = "postgresql://username@localhost/some_db" excludes = [ "sqlalchemy.profile" ] filters = [ "/**/tables/some_table" ]
docs.title: Schema

docs.text: Do not store database credentials in your settings.toml ; use Dynaconf's secret management instead. See Dynaconf's documentation for more information.
docs.title: Secrets

docs.text: Recap's crawler does three things: Browses the configured infrastructure Analyzes the infrastructure's data to generate metadata Stores the metadata in Recap's data catalog Behavior ¶ Recap's crawler is very simple right now. The crawler recursively browses and analyzes all children starting from an infrastructure's root location. Note The meaning of an infrastructure's root location depends on its type. For a database, the root usually denotes a database or catalog (to use information_schema terminology). For object stores, the root is usually the bucket location. Scheduling ¶ Recap's crawler does not have a built in scheduler or orchestrator. You can run crawls manually with recap crawl , or you can schedule recap crawl to run periodically using cron , Airflow , Prefect , Dagster , Modal , or any other scheduler. Commands ¶ Run recap crawl to begin crawling all configured infrastructure. You may optionall specify a URL to crawl: recap crawl postgresql://username@localhost/some_db See the commands page for crawler command details. Configuration ¶ See the configuration page for crawler configuration details.
docs.title: Crawler

docs.text: Recap's crawler is very simple right now. The crawler recursively browses and analyzes all children starting from an infrastructure's root location. Note The meaning of an infrastructure's root location depends on its type. For a database, the root usually denotes a database or catalog (to use information_schema terminology). For object stores, the root is usually the bucket location.
docs.title: Behavior

docs.text: Recap's crawler does not have a built in scheduler or orchestrator. You can run crawls manually with recap crawl , or you can schedule recap crawl to run periodically using cron , Airflow , Prefect , Dagster , Modal , or any other scheduler.
docs.title: Scheduling

docs.text: Run recap crawl to begin crawling all configured infrastructure. You may optionall specify a URL to crawl: recap crawl postgresql://username@localhost/some_db See the commands page for crawler command details.
docs.title: Commands

docs.text: See the configuration page for crawler configuration details.
docs.title: Configuration

docs.text: Recap uses Python's standard logging library. Logs are printed to standard out using Rich's logging handler by default. Customizing ¶ You can customize Recap's log output. Set the logging.config.path value in your settings.toml file to point at a TOML file that conforms to Python's dictConfig schema. version = 1 disable_existing_loggers = true formatters . standard . format = "%(asctime)s [%(levelname)s] %(name)s: %(message)s" [handlers.default] formatter = "standard" class = "rich.logging.RichHandler" show_time = false show_level = false show_path = false [loggers.""] handlers = [ 'default' ] level = "WARNING" propagate = false [loggers.recap] handlers = [ 'default' ] level = "INFO" propagate = false [loggers.uvicorn] handlers = [ 'default' ] level = "INFO" propagate = false
docs.title: Logging

docs.text: You can customize Recap's log output. Set the logging.config.path value in your settings.toml file to point at a TOML file that conforms to Python's dictConfig schema. version = 1 disable_existing_loggers = true formatters . standard . format = "%(asctime)s [%(levelname)s] %(name)s: %(message)s" [handlers.default] formatter = "standard" class = "rich.logging.RichHandler" show_time = false show_level = false show_path = false [loggers.""] handlers = [ 'default' ] level = "WARNING" propagate = false [loggers.recap] handlers = [ 'default' ] level = "INFO" propagate = false [loggers.uvicorn] handlers = [ 'default' ] level = "INFO" propagate = false
docs.title: Customizing

docs.text: You can extend Recap with plugins. In fact, everything in Recap is a plugin except for its crawler (and even that might change eventually). Plugins are implemented using Pythons entry-points package metadata. See Python's using pacakge metadata page for more details on this style of plugin architecture. There are five types of plugins: Analyzers Browsers Catalogs Commands Routers Analyzers ¶ Analyzer plugins must implement the AbstractAnalyzer class. Packages can export their analyzers using the recap.analyzers entry-point. Here's how Recap's built-in analyzers are defined in its pyproject.toml : [project.entry-points."recap.analyzers"] "db.location" = "recap.analyzers.db.location" "sqlalchemy.access" = "recap.analyzers.sqlalchemy.access" "sqlalchemy.columns" = "recap.analyzers.sqlalchemy.columns" "sqlalchemy.comment" = "recap.analyzers.sqlalchemy.comment" "sqlalchemy.foreign_keys" = "recap.analyzers.sqlalchemy.foreign_keys" "sqlalchemy.indexes" = "recap.analyzers.sqlalchemy.indexes" "sqlalchemy.primary_key" = "recap.analyzers.sqlalchemy.primary_key" "sqlalchemy.profile" = "recap.analyzers.sqlalchemy.profile" "sqlalchemy.view_definition" = "recap.analyzers.sqlalchemy.view_definition" Every entry-point points to a module with a create_analyzer(**config) method. Browsers ¶ Browser plugins must implement the AbstractBrowser class. Packages can export their browsers using the recap.browsers entry-point. Here's how Recap's built-in browser is defined in its pyproject.toml : [project.entry-points."recap.browsers"] db = "recap.browsers.db" Every entry-point points to a module with a create_browser(**config) method. Catalogs ¶ Catalog plugins must implement the AbstractCatalog class. Packages can export their catalogs using the recap.catalogs entry-point. Here's how Recap's built-in catalogs are defined in its pyproject.toml : [project.entry-points."recap.catalogs"] db = "recap.catalogs.db" recap = "recap.catalogs.recap" Every entry-point points to a module with a create_catalog(**config) method. Commands ¶ Command plugins use Typer . Plugins must expose a typer.Typer() object, usually defined as: app = typer . Typer () Packages can export their commands using the recap.commands entry-point. Here's how Recap's built-in commands are defined in its pyproject.toml : [project.entry-points."recap.commands"] catalog = "recap.commands.catalog:app" crawl = "recap.commands.crawl:app" plugins = "recap.commands.plugins:app" serve = "recap.commands.serve:app" Routers ¶ Server plugins use FastAPI . Plugins must expose a fastapi.APIRouter() object, usually defined as: router = fastapi . APIRouter () Packages can export their commands using the recap.routers entry-point. Here's how Recap's built-in routers are defined in its pyproject.toml : [project.entry-points."recap.routers"] "catalog.typed" = "recap.routers.catalog.typed:router" "catalog.untyped" = "recap.routers.catalog.untyped:router" Routers are added relative to the HTTP server's root path. Tip Recap calls include_router(route) for each object in the recap.routers entry-point. This means that anything that works with include_router can be exposed (even GraphQL APIs ). Warning Order matters when adding routers to FastAPI. Recap does not currently support router order prioritization; routers are added in an unpredictable order. If multiple routers contain the same path, the first one will handle incoming requests to its path.
docs.title: Plugins

docs.text: Analyzer plugins must implement the AbstractAnalyzer class. Packages can export their analyzers using the recap.analyzers entry-point. Here's how Recap's built-in analyzers are defined in its pyproject.toml : [project.entry-points."recap.analyzers"] "db.location" = "recap.analyzers.db.location" "sqlalchemy.access" = "recap.analyzers.sqlalchemy.access" "sqlalchemy.columns" = "recap.analyzers.sqlalchemy.columns" "sqlalchemy.comment" = "recap.analyzers.sqlalchemy.comment" "sqlalchemy.foreign_keys" = "recap.analyzers.sqlalchemy.foreign_keys" "sqlalchemy.indexes" = "recap.analyzers.sqlalchemy.indexes" "sqlalchemy.primary_key" = "recap.analyzers.sqlalchemy.primary_key" "sqlalchemy.profile" = "recap.analyzers.sqlalchemy.profile" "sqlalchemy.view_definition" = "recap.analyzers.sqlalchemy.view_definition" Every entry-point points to a module with a create_analyzer(**config) method.
docs.title: Analyzers

docs.text: Browser plugins must implement the AbstractBrowser class. Packages can export their browsers using the recap.browsers entry-point. Here's how Recap's built-in browser is defined in its pyproject.toml : [project.entry-points."recap.browsers"] db = "recap.browsers.db" Every entry-point points to a module with a create_browser(**config) method.
docs.title: Browsers

docs.text: Catalog plugins must implement the AbstractCatalog class. Packages can export their catalogs using the recap.catalogs entry-point. Here's how Recap's built-in catalogs are defined in its pyproject.toml : [project.entry-points."recap.catalogs"] db = "recap.catalogs.db" recap = "recap.catalogs.recap" Every entry-point points to a module with a create_catalog(**config) method.

docs.text: Command plugins use Typer . Plugins must expose a typer.Typer() object, usually defined as: app = typer . Typer () Packages can export their commands using the recap.commands entry-point. Here's how Recap's built-in commands are defined in its pyproject.toml : [project.entry-points."recap.commands"] catalog = "recap.commands.catalog:app" crawl = "recap.commands.crawl:app" plugins = "recap.commands.plugins:app" serve = "recap.commands.serve:app"
docs.title: Commands

docs.text: Server plugins use FastAPI . Plugins must expose a fastapi.APIRouter() object, usually defined as: router = fastapi . APIRouter () Packages can export their commands using the recap.routers entry-point. Here's how Recap's built-in routers are defined in its pyproject.toml : [project.entry-points."recap.routers"] "catalog.typed" = "recap.routers.catalog.typed:router" "catalog.untyped" = "recap.routers.catalog.untyped:router" Routers are added relative to the HTTP server's root path. Tip Recap calls include_router(route) for each object in the recap.routers entry-point. This means that anything that works with include_router can be exposed (even GraphQL APIs ). Warning Order matters when adding routers to FastAPI. Recap does not currently support router order prioritization; routers are added in an unpredictable order. If multiple routers contain the same path, the first one will handle incoming requests to its path.
docs.title: Routers

docs.text: Install ¶ Start by installing Recap. Python 3.10 or above is required. pip install recap-core Crawl ¶ Now let's crawl a database: CLI Python recap crawl postgresql://username@localhost/some_db from recap.analyzers.db.column import TableColumnAnalyzer from recap.browsers.db import DatabaseBrowser from recap.catalogs.db import DatabaseCatalog from recap.crawler import Crawler from sqlalchemy import create_engine some_db_engine = create_engine ( 'postgresql://username@localhost/some_db' ) catalog_engine = create_engine ( 'sqlite://' ) analyzers = [ TableColumnAnalyzer ( some_db_engine ), # Other analyzers can go here, too. ] browser = DatabaseBrowser ( some_db_engine ) catalog = DatabaseCatalog ( catalog_engine ) crawler = Crawler ( browser , catalog , analyzers ) crawler . crawl () You can use any SQLAlchemy connect string. recap crawl bigquery://some-project-12345 recap crawl snowflake://username:password@account_identifier/SOME_DB/SOME_SCHHEMA?warehouse=SOME_COMPUTE Note You must install appropriate drivers and SQLAlchemy dialects for the databases you wish to crawl. For PostgreSQL, you'll have to pip install psycopg2 . For Snowflake and BigQuery, you'll have to pip install snowflake-sqlalchemy or pip install sqlalchemy-bigquery , respectively. Or maybe you want to crawl a filesystem: recap crawl ~/data Or object store: recap crawl s3://power-analysis-ready-datastore Note You must install appropriate fsspec implementation for the filesystem you wish to crawl. List ¶ Crawled metadata is stored in a directory structure. See what's available using: CLI Python recap catalog list / from recap.catalogs.db import DatabaseCatalog from sqlalchemy import create_engine engine = create_engine ( 'sqlite://' ) catalog = DatabaseCatalog ( engine ) children = catalog . ls ( '/' ) Recap will respond with a JSON list in the CLI: [ "databases" , "filesystems" ] Append children to the path to browse around: CLI Python recap catalog list /databases from recap.catalogs.db import DatabaseCatalog from sqlalchemy import create_engine engine = create_engine ( 'sqlite://' ) catalog = DatabaseCatalog ( engine ) results = catalog . ls ( '/databases' ) Read ¶ After you poke around, try and read some metadata. Every node in the path can have metadata, but right now only tables and views do. You can look at metadata using the recap catalog read command: CLI Python recap catalog read /databases/postgresql/instances/localhost/schemas/some_db/tables/some_table from recap.catalogs.db import DatabaseCatalog from sqlalchemy import create_engine engine = create_engine ( 'sqlite://' ) catalog = DatabaseCatalog ( engine ) metadata = catalog . read ( '/databases/postgresql/instances/localhost/schemas/some_db/tables/some_table' ) Recap will print all of some_table 's metadata to the CLI in JSON format: { "sqlalchemy.access" : { "username" : { "privileges" : [ "INSERT" , "SELECT" , "UPDATE" , "DELETE" , "TRUNCATE" , "REFERENCES" , "TRIGGER" ], "read" : true , "write" : true } }, "sqlalchemy.columns" : { "email" : { "autoincrement" : false , "default" : null , "generic_type" : "VARCHAR" , "nullable" : false , "type" : "VARCHAR" }, "id" : { "autoincrement" : true , "default" : "nextval('\"some_db\".some_table_id_seq'::regclass)" , "generic_type" : "BIGINT" , "nullable" : false , "type" : "BIGINT" } }, "sqlalchemy.profile" : { "email" : { "count" : 10 , "distinct" : 10 , "empty_strings" : 0 , "max_length" : 32 , "min_length" : 13 , "nulls" : 0 }, "id" : { "average" : 5.5 , "count" : 10 , "max" : 10 , "min" : 1 , "negatives" : 0 , "nulls" : 0 , "sum" : 55.0 , "zeros" : 0 } }, "sqlalchemy.indexes" : { "index_some_table_on_email" : { "columns" : [ "email" ], "unique" : false } }, "db.location" : { "database" : "postgresql" , "instance" : "localhost" , "schema" : "some_db" , "table" : "some_table" }, "sqlalchemy.primary_key" : { "constrained_columns" : [ "id" ], "name" : "some_table_pkey" } } Search ¶ Recap stores its metadata in SQLite by default. You can use SQLite's json_extract syntax to search the catalog: CLI Python recap catalog search "json_extract(metadata, '$.\"db.location\".table') = 'some_table'" from recap.catalogs.db import DatabaseCatalog from sqlalchemy import create_engine engine = create_engine ( 'sqlite://' ) catalog = DatabaseCatalog ( engine ) results = catalog . search ( "json_extract(metadata, '$. \" db.location \" .table') = 'some_table'" ) The database file defaults to ~/.recap/catalog/recap.db , if you wish to open a SQLite client directly.
docs.title: Quickstart

For PostgreSQL, you'll have to pip install psycopg2 . For Snowflake and BigQuery, you'll have to pip install snowflake-sqlalchemy or pip install sqlalchemy-bigquery , respectively. Or maybe you want to crawl a filesystem: recap crawl ~/data Or object store: recap crawl s3://power-analysis-ready-datastore Note You must install appropriate fsspec implementation for the filesystem you wish to crawl.

You can use SQLite's json_extract syntax to search the catalog: CLI Python recap catalog search "json_extract(metadata, '$.\"db.location\".table') = 'some_table'" from recap.catalogs.db import DatabaseCatalog from sqlalchemy import create_engine engine = create_engine ( 'sqlite://' ) catalog = DatabaseCatalog ( engine ) results = catalog . search ( "json_extract(metadata, '$. \" db.location \" .table') = 'some_table'" ) The database file defaults to ~/.recap/catalog/recap.db , if you wish to open a SQLite client directly.

docs.text: Recap comes with an HTTP/JSON API server implementation of Recap's catalog interface. The server allows non-Python systems to integrate with Recap. The server also allows metadata to be shared amgonst different systems when they all point to the same server. Starting ¶ Execute recap serve to start Recap's server. Configuring ¶ Recap's server is implemented as a FastAPI in a uvicorn web server. Any configuration set in your settings.toml file under the server.uvicorn namespace will be passed to Recap's uvicorn.run invocation. [server] uvicorn . port = 9000 You can also enable only certain router plugins using the server.plugins setting: [server] plugins = [ "catalog.typed" ] Endpoints ¶ Recap has the following endpoints: GET /catalog?query=<query> - Search the Recap catalog. GET | PUT | PATCH /catalog/{path}/metadata - Read, write, or remove metadata. GET /catalog/{path}/children - List a path's child directories. DELETE /catalog/{path} - Delete a path, its metadata, and its children. Recap's JSON schema is visible at http://localhost:8000/openapi.json . API documentation is also visible at http://localhost:8000/docs and http://localhost:8000/redoc . Models ¶ Recap's catalog router plugin comes in two flavors: typed and untyped. The endpoints listed above are untyped--metadata is a dict[str, Any] . Typed endpoints use Pydantic data models from analyzers to define strongly typed (and validated) metadata models. Recap's server turns on both routers by default. Interacting with typed paths will validate metadata JSON. Interacting with untyped paths will allow arbitrary JSON dictionaries through. A typed path looks something like this: /catalog/databases/{scheme}/instances/{name}/schemas/{schema}/views/{view}/metadata Examples ¶ The following examples illlustrate how to call a Recap server running at http://localhost:8000 . Write metadata ¶ curl -X PATCH 'http://localhost:8000/catalog/databases/postgresql/instances/some_instance/schemas/some_db/tables/some_table/metadata' \ -d '{"comment": "This is some table"}' \ -H "Content-Type: application/json" Read metadata ¶ curl 'http://localhost:8000/catalog/databases/postgresql/instances/some_instance/schemas/some_db/tables/some_table/metadata' Read a directory ¶ curl http://localhost:8000/catalog/databases/postgresql/children Delete a directory ¶ curl -X DELETE 'http://localhost:8000/catalog/databases/postgresql/instances/some_instance/schemas/some_db/tables/some_table'
docs.title: Server

docs.text: Execute recap serve to start Recap's server.
docs.title: Starting

Any configuration set in your settings.toml file under the server.uvicorn namespace will be passed to Recap's uvicorn.run invocation. [server] uvicorn . port = 9000 You can also enable only certain router plugins using the server.plugins setting: [server] plugins = [ "catalog.typed" ]

GET /catalog/{path}/children - List a path's child directories. DELETE /catalog/{path} - Delete a path, its metadata, and its children. Recap's JSON schema is visible at http://localhost:8000/openapi.json . API documentation is also visible at http://localhost:8000/docs and http://localhost:8000/redoc .

Typed endpoints use Pydantic data models from analyzers to define strongly typed (and validated) metadata models. Recap's server turns on both routers by default. Interacting with typed paths will validate metadata JSON. Interacting with untyped paths will allow arbitrary JSON dictionaries through. A typed path looks something like this: /catalog/databases/{scheme}/instances/{name}/schemas/{schema}/views/{view}/metadata

docs.text: recap.analyzers.abstract ¶ AbstractAnalyzer ¶ Bases: ABC The abstract class for all analyzers. Analyzers are responsible for inspecting data and returning metadata. analyze ( path ) abstractmethod ¶ Analyze a path for an infrastructure instance. Only the path is specified because the URL for the instance is passed in via the config in open() . Returns: Type Description BaseMetadataModel | None BaseMetadataModel Pydantic BaseModel, which represents discovered metadata. This data gets serialized as JSON in the catalog. recap.analyzers.genson ¶ columns ¶ FileColumnAnalyzer ¶ Bases: AbstractAnalyzer __init__ ( fs , base_path , sample = 1024 ) ¶ Parameters: Name Type Description Default fs AbstractFileSystem An fsspec filesystem to read files from. required base_path str The path portion of the URL to read from. Acts as the root path for child paths. required sample int | None If set, read the first N rows of a JSON file when inferring its schema. Sometimes preferable for performance reasons. 1024
docs.title: recap.analyzers

docs.text: Bases: ABC The abstract class for all analyzers. Analyzers are responsible for inspecting data and returning metadata.
docs.title: AbstractAnalyzer

docs.text: Analyze a path for an infrastructure instance. Only the path is specified because the URL for the instance is passed in via the config in open() . Returns: Type Description BaseMetadataModel | None BaseMetadataModel Pydantic BaseModel, which represents discovered metadata. This data gets serialized as JSON in the catalog.
docs.title: analyze()

docs.text: Bases: AbstractAnalyzer
docs.title: FileColumnAnalyzer

docs.text: Parameters: Name Type Description Default fs AbstractFileSystem An fsspec filesystem to read files from. required base_path str The path portion of the URL to read from. Acts as the root path for child paths. required sample int | None If set, read the first N rows of a JSON file when inferring its schema. Sometimes preferable for performance reasons. 1024
docs.title: __init__()

docs.text: recap.browsers.abstract ¶ AbstractBrowser ¶ Bases: ABC The abstract class for all browsers. Recap uses a browser abstraction to deal with different data infrastructure in a standard way. Browsers map infrastructure objects into a directory format. A different browser is used for each type of infrastructure. A DatabaseBrowser might list directories like this: /schemas /schemas/public /schemas/public/tables /schemas/public/tables/groups /schemas/public/tables/users children ( path ) abstractmethod ¶ Given a path, returns its children. Using the example above, path=/schemas/public/tables would return: [ TablePath( schema='public', table='groups', ), TablePath( schema='public', table='users', ), ] The path parameter is relative; it does not include the browser's root. root () abstractmethod ¶ The root path for this browser. The root path is prefixed to all paths when persisting metdata to a catalog. Using the example above, root might return something like: /databases/postgresql/instances/prd-db Thus, the full catalog path for the users table would be: /databases/postgresql/instances/prd-db/schemas/public/tables/users recap.browsers.analyzing ¶ AnalyzingBrowser ¶ Bases: AbstractBrowser A special browser that ties an AbstractBrowser together with its compatible AbstractAnalyzers. Browsers and analyzers are deliberately unaware of one another, but something has to tie them together. That's this class. AnalyzingBrowser takes in a browser and its compatible analyzers. It provides all of the same functionality as the wrapped browser, but it also exposes an analyze() method, which runs all analyzers on a path and returns the analyzed metadata. This browser is deliberately not added to Recap's browser plugin entrypoint. It's more of a utility class for the CLI and crawler. create_browser ( ** config ) ¶ Create an AnalyzingBrowser that wraps an AbstractBrowser and AbstractAnalyzers that are compatible with the browser's child CatalogPaths. Note that the plugin config is currently ignored. This method simply searches for the first AbstractBrowser that doesn't throw an exception when its create_browser method is called. Parameters: Name Type Description Default config A **kwargs config for the browser to wrap. {} recap.browsers.db ¶ DatabaseBrowser ¶ Bases: AbstractBrowser A browser that lists database objects. DatabaseBrowser uses SQLAlchemy and its supported dialects ( https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/dialects/ ). DatabaseBrowser follows this directory sturcture: /databases/<scheme>/instances/<instance>/schemas/<schema>/tables/<table> /databases/<scheme>/instances/<instance>/schemas/<schema>/views/<view> The scheme is derived from the DB URL (e.g. postgres://user:pass@localhost/my_db would have scheme="postgres"). The instance defaults to the hostname, but can be overridden via the name config. Schema is whatever SQLAlchemy returns from get_schema_names . Ditto for table and view. This model does not make the distinction between schemas and databases as defined in standard information_schema formats ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_schema ). PostgreSQL, in particular, is a little weird because it has both (the schema is usually public ). schemas () ¶ Returns: Type Description list [ str ] All schema names in a database. In PostgreSQL, this is usually just public . In MySQL and others, it's usually a list of all database names. tables ( schema ) ¶ Returns: Type Description list [ str ] All table names in a schema. views ( schema ) ¶ Returns: Type Description list [ str ] All view names in a schema. recap.browsers.fs ¶ FilesystemBrowser ¶ Bases: AbstractBrowser A browser that lists filesystem objects. FilesystemBrowser uses fsspec and its supported implementations ( https://filesystem-spec.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#built-in-implementations ). FilesystemBrowser mirrors the directory structure in the filesystem. create_browser ( url , name = None , storage_options = {}, ** _ ) ¶ Parameters: Name Type Description Default url str The URL to use for the filesystem. If the URL contains a path, the FilesystemBrowser will treat all paths relative to the URL path. required name str | None The name to use in the FilesystemRootPath. If unspecified, the URL host is used (or 'localhost' for 'file' schemes). None storage_options dict [ str , Any ] Storage options **kwargs to pass on to the fsspec filesystem constructor. {}
docs.title: recap.browsers

docs.text: Bases: ABC The abstract class for all browsers. Recap uses a browser abstraction to deal with different data infrastructure in a standard way. Browsers map infrastructure objects into a directory format. A different browser is used for each type of infrastructure. A DatabaseBrowser might list directories like this: /schemas /schemas/public /schemas/public/tables /schemas/public/tables/groups /schemas/public/tables/users

Using the example above, root might return something like: /databases/postgresql/instances/prd-db Thus, the full catalog path for the users table would be: /databases/postgresql/instances/prd-db/schemas/public/tables/users

docs.text: Bases: AbstractBrowser A special browser that ties an AbstractBrowser together with its compatible AbstractAnalyzers. Browsers and analyzers are deliberately unaware of one another, but something has to tie them together. That's this class. AnalyzingBrowser takes in a browser and its compatible analyzers. It provides all of the same functionality as the wrapped browser, but it also exposes an analyze() method, which runs all analyzers on a path and returns the analyzed metadata. This browser is deliberately not added to Recap's browser plugin entrypoint. It's more of a utility class for the CLI and crawler.
docs.title: AnalyzingBrowser

docs.text: Create an AnalyzingBrowser that wraps an AbstractBrowser and AbstractAnalyzers that are compatible with the browser's child CatalogPaths. Note that the plugin config is currently ignored. This method simply searches for the first AbstractBrowser that doesn't throw an exception when its create_browser method is called. Parameters: Name Type Description Default config A **kwargs config for the browser to wrap. {}
docs.title: create_browser()

docs.text: Bases: AbstractBrowser A browser that lists database objects. DatabaseBrowser uses SQLAlchemy and its supported dialects ( https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/dialects/ ). DatabaseBrowser follows this directory sturcture: /databases/<scheme>/instances/<instance>/schemas/<schema>/tables/<table> /databases/<scheme>/instances/<instance>/schemas/<schema>/views/<view> The scheme is derived from the DB URL (e.g. postgres://user:pass@localhost/my_db would have scheme="postgres"). The instance defaults to the hostname, but can be overridden via the name config. Schema is whatever SQLAlchemy returns from get_schema_names . Ditto for table and view. This model does not make the distinction between schemas and databases as defined in standard information_schema formats ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_schema ). PostgreSQL, in particular, is a little weird because it has both (the schema is usually public ).
docs.title: DatabaseBrowser

docs.text: Returns: Type Description list [ str ] All schema names in a database. In PostgreSQL, this is usually just public . In MySQL and others, it's usually a list of all database names.
docs.title: schemas()

docs.text: Returns: Type Description list [ str ] All table names in a schema.
docs.title: tables()

docs.text: Returns: Type Description list [ str ] All view names in a schema.
docs.title: views()

docs.text: Bases: AbstractBrowser A browser that lists filesystem objects. FilesystemBrowser uses fsspec and its supported implementations ( https://filesystem-spec.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#built-in-implementations ). FilesystemBrowser mirrors the directory structure in the filesystem.
docs.title: FilesystemBrowser

docs.text: Parameters: Name Type Description Default url str The URL to use for the filesystem. If the URL contains a path, the FilesystemBrowser will treat all paths relative to the URL path. required name str | None The name to use in the FilesystemRootPath. If unspecified, the URL host is used (or 'localhost' for 'file' schemes). None storage_options dict [ str , Any ] Storage options **kwargs to pass on to the fsspec filesystem constructor. {}
docs.title: create_browser()

docs.text: recap.catalogs.abstract ¶ AbstractCatalog ¶ Bases: ABC The abstract class for all catalogs. Recap catalogs store metadata and expose read and search APIs. Catalogs follow the same directory structure as AbstractBrowsers. ls ( path , time = None ) abstractmethod ¶ Returns all children in a directory. This method does not signal whether or not a directory has metadata, since metadata is not a child of a directory. To check if a path has metadata, call read . Returns: Type Description list [ str ] | None A list of child names. Does not include absolute path. read ( path , time = None ) abstractmethod ¶ Read all metadata in a directory. Returns: Type Description dict [ str , Any ] | None Metadata dictionary of the format {"metadata_type": Any}. rm ( path ) abstractmethod ¶ Remove a directory or metadata entry. If type is note set, the whole directory (including all children and metadata) is removed. Parameters: Name Type Description Default type If specified, the type of metadata to delete. required search ( query , time = None ) abstractmethod ¶ Searches an entire catalog for metadata. The query syntax is dependent on the catalog implementation. Parameters: Name Type Description Default query str A query string to match against metadata in a catalog. required touch ( path ) abstractmethod ¶ Creates an empty directory. write ( path , metadata , patch = True ) abstractmethod ¶ Writes metadata to a directory location. Parameters: Name Type Description Default type Metadata types can be any string. Common examples are "schema", "pii", "indexes", "profile", and so on. Types are defined based on the data that AbstractAnalyzers return. required recap.catalogs.db ¶ DatabaseCatalog ¶ Bases: AbstractCatalog DatabaseCatalog stores metadata entries in a catalog table using SQLAlchemy. The table has three main columns: parent, name, and metadata. The parent and name columns reflect the directory for the metadata (as defined by an AbstractBrowser). The metadata column contains a JSON blob of all the various metadata types and objects. Previous metadata versions are kept in catalog as well. A deleted_at field is used to tombstone deleted directories. Directories that were updated, not deleted, will not have a deleted_at set; there will just be a more recent row (as sorted by id ). Reads return the most recent metadata that was written to the path. If the most recent record has a deleted_at tombstone, an None is returned. Search strings are simply passed along to the WHERE clause in a SELECT statement. This does leave room for SQL injection attacks; not thrilled about that. recap.catalogs.recap ¶ RecapCatalog ¶ Bases: AbstractCatalog RecapCatalog makes HTTP requests to a Recap server and returns the results.
docs.title: recap.catalogs

docs.text: Bases: ABC The abstract class for all catalogs. Recap catalogs store metadata and expose read and search APIs. Catalogs follow the same directory structure as AbstractBrowsers.
docs.title: AbstractCatalog

docs.text: Returns all children in a directory. This method does not signal whether or not a directory has metadata, since metadata is not a child of a directory. To check if a path has metadata, call read . Returns: Type Description list [ str ] | None A list of child names. Does not include absolute path.
docs.title: ls()

docs.text: Read all metadata in a directory. Returns: Type Description dict [ str , Any ] | None Metadata dictionary of the format {"metadata_type": Any}.
docs.title: read()

docs.text: Remove a directory or metadata entry. If type is note set, the whole directory (including all children and metadata) is removed. Parameters: Name Type Description Default type If specified, the type of metadata to delete. required
docs.title: rm()

docs.text: Searches an entire catalog for metadata. The query syntax is dependent on the catalog implementation. Parameters: Name Type Description Default query str A query string to match against metadata in a catalog. required
docs.title: search()

docs.text: Creates an empty directory.
docs.title: touch()

docs.text: Writes metadata to a directory location. Parameters: Name Type Description Default type Metadata types can be any string. Common examples are "schema", "pii", "indexes", "profile", and so on. Types are defined based on the data that AbstractAnalyzers return. required
docs.title: write()

docs.text: Bases: AbstractCatalog DatabaseCatalog stores metadata entries in a catalog table using SQLAlchemy. The table has three main columns: parent, name, and metadata. The parent and name columns reflect the directory for the metadata (as defined by an AbstractBrowser). The metadata column contains a JSON blob of all the various metadata types and objects. Previous metadata versions are kept in catalog as well. A deleted_at field is used to tombstone deleted directories. Directories that were updated, not deleted, will not have a deleted_at set; there will just be a more recent row (as sorted by id ). Reads return the most recent metadata that was written to the path. If the most recent record has a deleted_at tombstone, an None is returned. Search strings are simply passed along to the WHERE clause in a SELECT statement. This does leave room for SQL injection attacks; not thrilled about that.
docs.title: DatabaseCatalog

docs.text: Bases: AbstractCatalog RecapCatalog makes HTTP requests to a Recap server and returns the results.
docs.title: RecapCatalog

docs.text: recap.crawler.Crawler ¶ Crawler does three things: Browses the configured infrastructure Analyzes the infrastructure's data to generate metadata Stores the metadata in a catalog __init__ ( browser , catalog , recursive = True , filters = []) ¶ Parameters: Name Type Description Default browser AnalyzingBrowser AnalyzingBrowser to use for listing children and analyzing metadata. required catalog AbstractCatalog The catalog where the crawler will create directories and store metadata. required recursive bool Whether the crawler should recurse into subdirectories when crawling. True filters list [ str ] Path filter to include only certain paths. Recap uses Unix filename pattern matching as defined in Python's fnmatch module. Filtered paths are relative to the browser (excluding the browser's root). []
docs.title: recap.crawler

docs.title: __init__()

docs.text: recap.paths.CatalogPath ¶ Bases: BaseModel Represents a path in the data catalog. template : ClassVar [ str ] class-attribute ¶ A list of templated paths that represent the various locations of this path type. The template format uses Starlette's simplified URI style. For example: /databases/{scheme}/instances/{instance}/schemas/{schema} __str__ () ¶ Find a template format that has parameters compatible with this instance. If one is found, fill it in with this instance's attributes and return it. For example, a template: /databases/{scheme}/instances/{instance}/schemas/{schema} Would return: /databases/postgresql/instances/localhost/schemas/public If the instance had: SomeCatalogPath( scheme='postgresql', instance='localhost', schema='public'] ) from_path ( path ) classmethod ¶ Construct this model from a path if it matches the template. recap.paths.RootPath ¶ Bases: CatalogPath Canonical root path for the catalog. recap . paths . create_catalog_path ( path , * types ) ¶ Given a collection of CatalogPath types, find one that has a template that matches the provided path. If a matching path is found, instantiate the CatalogPath type and return it.
docs.title: recap.paths

docs.text: recap.routers.catalog ¶ typed ¶ This module dynamically adds all available browser paths to a router. The module works using type hints. It inspects both the children() and analyze() methods for each browser and analyzer. It then infers which analyzers can analyze paths from each browser. The module uses this information to construct Pydantic models that contain all compatible analyzers for each path. It adds these paths and models to the router. add_metadata_paths ( router ) ¶ Dynamically adds all browser paths to the router. add_metadata_paths looks at the children() method's return CatalogPaths for each browser, and gets all analyzers that analyze one or more of those paths. The method then gets the return Pydantic models for each analyze and combines them into an uber-Metadata model. A GET/PUT/PATCH endpoint is added for each of these models. Parameters: Name Type Description Default router APIRouter Router to add metadata routes to. required add_route ( router , endpoint , method , browser_root_path_class , child_path_class , response_model = None ) ¶ Adds a metadata endpoint to a router. The endpoint's signature is overwritten to include the fields from the root and child paths. root=/databases/{scheme}/instances/{name} child=/schemas/{schema} Would result in scheme, name, and schema parameters being added to the endpoint. This will cause FastAPI to pass these path parameters into the endpoint, which allows the _metadata methods below to grab them in *kwargs. Parameters: Name Type Description Default router APIRouter The router to add a route to. required endpoint Callable The endpoint (method) to add to the router. required method str GET, PUT, POST, PATCH, DELETE, and so on. required browser_root_path Browser's root path to be used in HTTP path. required child_path Child path relative to browser's root to be used in HTTP path. required response_model type [ BaseModel ] | None The response_model class for GET methods. None add_routes ( router , metadata_class , browser_root_path_class , child_path_class ) ¶ Helper method that adds GET, PUT, and PATCH routes to a router for a given model/browser path combination. Parameters: Name Type Description Default router APIRouter The router to add routes to. required metadata_class type [ BaseModel ] The Pydantic metadata model that represents metadata for the root/child path. required browser_root_path Browser's root path to be used in HTTP path. required child_path Child path relative to browser's root to be used in HTTP path. required
docs.title: recap.routers

docs.text: This module dynamically adds all available browser paths to a router. The module works using type hints. It inspects both the children() and analyze() methods for each browser and analyzer. It then infers which analyzers can analyze paths from each browser. The module uses this information to construct Pydantic models that contain all compatible analyzers for each path. It adds these paths and models to the router.

This will cause FastAPI to pass these path parameters into the endpoint, which allows the _metadata methods below to grab them in *kwargs. Parameters: Name Type Description Default router APIRouter The router to add a route to. required endpoint Callable The endpoint (method) to add to the router. required method str GET, PUT, POST, PATCH, DELETE, and so on. required browser_root_path Browser's root path to be used in HTTP path. required child_path Child path relative to browser's root to be used in HTTP path. required response_model type [ BaseModel ] | None The response_model class for GET methods.
